question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)\end{align*}

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

In which direction does the temperature decrease most rapidly?
sols:
For any given unit vector $\displaystyle {}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}$, the
rate of change of temperature at \emph{P} in direction
$\displaystyle {}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}$ is the scalar

\begin{align*}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1) &= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot\widehat{\mathbf{u}} \\
&= \left\vert \nabla T(1,2,-1) \right\vert \,\left\vert\widehat{\mathbf{u}}\right\vert\cos(\theta) \\
&= \left\vert \nabla T(1,2,-1) \right\vert \cos(\theta)\end{align*}

where $\theta$ is the angle between the given vectors. (Recall that
$\displaystyle {}\vert{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}}\vert=1$.) For optimum
\emph{decrease}, we should make the directional derivative as small as
possible. Since our only degree of freedom is the angle above and we
know that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}-1\leq\cos\theta\leq1\end{align*}

we should arrange $\displaystyle {}\cos\theta=-1$ by choosing $\theta$=$\pi$, i.e.,
by making $\displaystyle {} \widehat{\mathbf{u}}$ parallel to
$-\nabla T(1,2,-1)$:

\begin{align*}\widehat{\mathbf{u}} = \frac{-\nabla T(1,2,-1)}{\left\vert -\nabla T(1,2,-1)\right\vert}
= \frac{\left\langle 2,2,-3\right\rangle}{\sqrt{17}}\end{align*} This is the
direction of most rapid temperature decrease.
hints:
Recall that for two vectors

\begin{align*}\mathbf{a}\cdot\mathbf{b}=|\mathbf{a}||\mathbf{b}|\cos\theta.\end{align*}

How would we choose $\theta$ to make this dot product the smallest? How
can we relate this idea to the directional derivative?
